member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncQueue`1.completedSource
member.summary: The source of the task returned by . Lazily constructed.
member.remarks: Volatile to allow our check-lock-check pattern in to be reliable, in the event that within the lock, one thread initializes the value and assigns the field and the weak memory model allows the assignment prior to the initialization. Another thread outside the lock might observe the non-null field and start accessing the Task property before it is actually initialized. Volatile prevents CPU reordering of commands around the assignment (or read) of this field.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock
member.summary: A non-blocking lock that allows concurrent access, exclusive access, or concurrent with upgradeability to exclusive access.
member.remarks: We have to use a custom awaitable rather than simply returning Task{LockReleaser} because we have to set CallContext data in the context of the person receiving the lock, which requires that we get to execute code at the start of the continuation (whether we yield or not).
member.devnotes:
Considering this class to be a state machine, the states are:
------------- | | <-----> READERS | IDLE | <-----> UPGRADEABLE READER + READERS -----> UPGRADED WRITER --\ | NO LOCKS | ^ | | | |--- RE-ENTER CONCURRENCY PREP <--/ | | <-----> WRITER -------------

member.summary: A CallContext-local reference to the Awaiter that is on the top of the stack (most recently acquired).

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.issuedReadLocks
member.summary: The set of read locks that are issued and active.
member.remarks: Many readers are allowed concurrently. Also, readers may re-enter read locks (recursively) each of which gets an element in this set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.issuedUpgradeableReadLocks
member.summary: The set of upgradeable read locks that are issued and active.
member.remarks: Although only one upgradeable read lock can be held at a time, this set may have more than one element because that one lock holder may enter the lock it already possesses multiple times.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.issuedWriteLocks
member.summary: The set of write locks that are issued and active.
member.remarks: Although only one write lock can be held at a time, this set may have more than one element because that one lock holder may enter the lock it already possesses multiple times. Although this lock is mutually exclusive, there *may* be elements in the set if the write lock was upgraded from a reader. Also note that some elements in this may themselves be upgradeable readers if they have the flag.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.waitingReaders
member.summary: A queue of readers waiting to obtain the concurrent read lock.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.waitingUpgradeableReaders
member.summary: A queue of upgradeable readers waiting to obtain a lock.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.waitingWriters
member.summary: A queue of writers waiting to obtain an exclusive lock.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.completionSource
member.summary: The source of the task, which transitions to completed after the method is called and all issued locks have been released.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.beforeWriteReleasedCallbacks
member.summary: The queue of callbacks to invoke when the currently held write lock is totally released.
member.remarks: If the write lock is released to an upgradeable read lock, these callbacks are fired synchronously with respect to the writer who is releasing the lock. Otherwise, the callbacks are invoked asynchronously with respect to the releasing thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.HideLocks
member.summary: Prevents use or visibility of the caller's lock(s) until the returned value is disposed.
member.returns: The value to dispose to restore lock visibility.
member.remarks: This can be used by a write lock holder that is about to fork execution to avoid two threads simultaneously believing they hold the exclusive write lock. The lock should be hidden just before kicking off the work and can be restored immediately after kicking off the work.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.Complete
member.summary: Causes new top-level lock requests to be rejected and the task to transition to a completed state after any issued locks have been released.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.OnBeforeWriteLockReleased(System.Func{System.Threading.Tasks.Task})
member.summary: Registers a callback to be invoked when the write lock held by the caller is about to be ultimately released (outermost write lock).
member.param: The asynchronous delegate to invoke. Access to the write lock is provided throughout the asynchronous invocation.
member.remarks: This supports some scenarios VC++ has where change event handlers need to inspect changes, or follow up with other changes to respond to earlier changes, at the conclusion of the lock. This method is safe to call from within a previously registered callback, in which case the registered callback will run when previously registered callbacks have completed execution. If the write lock is released to an upgradeable read lock, these callbacks are fired synchronously with respect to the writer who is releasing the lock. Otherwise, the callbacks are invoked asynchronously with respect to the releasing thread.

member.returns: true if all flags are found somewhere in the lock stack; false otherwise.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.LockFlags.StickyWrite
member.summary: Causes an upgradeable reader to remain in an upgraded-write state once upgraded, even after the nested write lock has been released.
member.remarks: This is useful when you have a batch of possible write operations to apply, which may or may not actually apply in the end, but if any of them change anything, all of their changes should be seen atomically (within a single write lock). This approach is preferable to simply acquiring a write lock around the batch of potential changes because it doesn't defeat concurrent readers until it knows there is a change to actually make.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterResourceLock`2.LockFlags.StickyWrite
member.summary: Causes an upgradeable reader to remain in an upgraded-write state once upgraded, even after the nested write lock has been released.
member.remarks: This is useful when you have a batch of possible write operations to apply, which may or may not actually apply in the end, but if any of them change anything, all of their changes should be seen atomically (within a single write lock). This approach is preferable to simply acquiring a write lock around the batch of potential changes because it doesn't defeat concurrent readers until it knows there is a change to actually make.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterResourceLock`2.LockFlags.SkipInitialPreparation
member.summary: Skips a step to make sure that the resource is initially prepared when retrieved using GetResourceAsync.
member.remarks: This flag is dormant for non-write locks. But if present on an upgradeable read lock, this flag will activate for a nested write lock.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskFactory.VerifyNoNonConcurrentSyncContext
member.summary: Throws an exception if an active AsyncReaderWriterLock upgradeable read or write lock is held by the caller.
member.remarks: This is important to call from the Run and Run{T} methods because if they are called from within an ARWL upgradeable read or write lock, then Run will synchronously block while inside the semaphore held by the ARWL that prevents concurrency. If the delegate within Run yields and then tries to reacquire the ARWL lock, it will be unable to re-enter the semaphore, leading to a deadlock. Instead, callers who hold UR/W locks should never call Run, or should switch to the STA thread first in order to exit the semaphore before calling the Run method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTask.Join(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Synchronously blocks the calling thread until the operation has completed. If the caller is on the Main thread (or is executing within a JoinableTask that has access to the main thread) the caller's access to the Main thread propagates to this JoinableTask so that it may also access the main thread.
member.param: A cancellation token that will exit this method before the task is completed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTask.JoinAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Shares any access to the main thread the caller may have Joins any main thread affinity of the caller with the asynchronous operation to avoid deadlocks in the event that the main thread ultimately synchronously blocks waiting for the operation to complete.
member.param: A cancellation token that will revert the Join and cause the returned task to complete before the async operation has completed.
member.returns: A task that completes after the asynchronous operation completes and the join is reverted.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskContext.syncContextLock
member.summary: A "global" lock that allows the graph of interconnected sync context and JoinableSet instances communicate in a thread-safe way without fear of deadlocks due to each taking their own private lock and then calling others, thus leading to deadlocks from lock ordering issues.
member.remarks: Yes, global locks should be avoided wherever possible. However even MEF from the .NET Framework uses a global lock around critical composition operations because containers can be interconnected in arbitrary ways. The code in this file has a very similar problem, so we use the same solution.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskContext.SuppressRelevance
member.summary: Conceals any JoinableTask the caller is associate with until the returned value is disposed.
member.returns: A value to dispose of to restore visibility into the caller's associated JoinableTask, if any.

remarks.para: It may be that while inside a delegate supplied to that async work be spun off such that it does not have privileges to re-enter the Main thread till the call has returned and the UI thread is idle. To prevent the async work from automatically being allowed to re-enter the Main thread, wrap the code that calls the async task in a using block with a call to this method as the expression.

remarks.para: It may be that while inside a delegate supplied to that async work be spun off such that it does not have privileges to re-enter the Main thread till the call has returned and the UI thread is idle. To prevent the async work from automatically being allowed to re-enter the Main thread, wrap the code that calls the async task in a using block with a call to this method as the expression.
